item.title: The 360° Skyline Song Project
item.description:
The 360° Skyline Song is an audiovisual installation work that makes sound waves from the visual “boundary” between surrounding scenery and sky. The visual data, made by recording the surrounding scenery with a video camera rotating an angle of 360 degrees, are transformed into sound waves in real time by analyzing each camera frame. By acquiring the color temperature and the air temperature there simultaneously, ‘The 360° Skyline Song’ improvises the expressive synthesis unique to the moment, so they are live and impressive to the audience. Both audio and visual data achieve the intuitive recognition of the transition of the boundary in sceneries. This installation implies the instability of surroundings, by interactively producing sound from changing surroundings and showing the captured movie.

Technical cooperation    Kazunori Ogasawara

item.description:
Katsufumi Matsui

Katsufumi Matsui is a PhD student at The University of Tokyo Graduate School of Interdisciplinary Information Studies. He was born in 1985 in Yamagata. His works are focused in the areas of sound installation, audiovisual performances, image sonification and new interface for musical expression. His works have been selected for participation in international conferences, such as the ISEA, NIME, ICMC. He has received various awards, such as 2014 Asia Digital Art Award Finalist Prizes, 20th Campus Genius Award BRONZE, the Digital Signage Award 2014 Special Prize and the Good Design Award 2011 in Japan.
